This is one of the things that I intend on changing in the docs. I've noticed all the instances of "cache definition" too. I'm also guilty of using that phrase. I'll update the terminology docs to add definitions for these two.

@rigazilla Maybe but I'm not sure. What do you think is missing or how should we change the definition?
For me, the "cache configuration" is the thing/artefact you use to enable features and define how you want Infinispan to behave. Which is distinct to a "configuration template" (a thing from which you create configurations). In docs I've seen configuration, template, and definition used inconsistently/interchangeably. Cheers.

replies.bodyText:
One more thing that probably needs to change for this to make sense: currently, a Configuration object does not include the cache name.
Perhaps that's why in some places we use "cache definition" instead of "cache configuration: Because "cache configuration" can be interpreted as the Configuration object, without the cache name, and XML document or element defining a cache does include the cache name, so it's somehow more than just a cache configuration.
/cc @tristantarrant @ryanemerson

@@ -0,0 +1,88 @@
+[[terminology]]
+= {brandname} Terminology
+
+{brandname} terminology refers to words and phrases specific to {brandname}
+capabilities and features. It is important to use consistent terminology across
+documentation and the code base to avoid unclear or contradictory language.
+
+Add::
+Add an item to an existing list, group, view, or other container element. For example, "add entries to caches".
+
+Cache configuration::
+An XML or JSON document that controls {brandname} behavior.
+
+Cache template::
+An artifact from which you create cache configurations. +
+{brandname} provides some pre-defined templates (`org.infinispan.*`). +
+Users can define new templates in `infinispan.xml` with the `*-cache-configuration*` tags. +
+In some APIs, you can use the configuration of an existing cache as a template to configure a new cache.
+
+Cache definition::
+Do not use to mean "cache configuration".
+
+Cache Manager::
+Interface for creating and managing caches. Always spell as two words with capital letters when referring to the abstract notion of a Cache Manager. +
+When referring to specific interfaces, use `CacheManager`, `EmbeddedCacheManager`, or `RemoteCacheManager`.
+
+Clear::
+Delete all the elements of a container. For example, "clear entries in a cache".
+
+Create::
+Build something new. For example, "create a cache".
+
+Delete::
+Remove a single element or a group of similar elements from a container. For example, "delete an entry from the cache" or "delete all expired entries from the cache".
+
+Destroy::
+Do not use to mean "delete".
+
+Index::
+Create an index to improve query performance or add an entry to an existing index when it is added to a cache.
+
+Indexes::
+Plural of index. Do not use "indices".
+
+Purge::
+Can have negative connotations and is not a preferred term. Use only as a synonym for "clear" or "delete" in subsequent descriptions, such as in the body text of a dialog or text that follows a heading. Do not use as a primary verb or in headings.
+
+Query::
+Look up information within the data set. The words "query" and "search" are synonymous but frequently interchanging the two can lead to inconsistency.
++
+Use in verb form: "Query values in the cache." +
+Use in noun form preceded by Ickle: "Perform an Ickle query on the cache."
+
+Reindex::
+Rebuild an index to update or change an existing index. Do not hyphenate (always "reindex" never "re-index").
+
+Remove::
+Use as a synonym for "clear" or "delete" in subsequent descriptions, such as in the body text of a dialog or text that follows a heading. Do not use as a primary verb or in headings.
+
+Reset::
+Restore an initial value or state. For example, "Reset a counter."
+
+Search::
+Synonymous with "query" but not preferred. In verb form, use with common phrases like "full-text search" in conjunction with {brandname} Query API. In noun form when referring to the `org.infinispan.query.Search` entry point.
++

timeline.bodyText:
We might want to remove this line. In general, we try to avoid synonyms in the UI since the inconsistency can lead to confusion (like using “log in” in one area and “sign in” in another). There are certainly times where it's fine to use a synonym, but we might not want to encourage it.
Instead, we could note that you should include important keywords in the heading, “like permanent.” This is what we have in PatternFly for reference:
Depending on your design template, follow this format for confirmation dialogs:
- Headline: A headline is usually phrased as a question. Include important keywords (like “permanent”) in the headline.
- Body text: Body text gives information about the action’s consequence.
- Buttons: Buttons allow a user to answer the headline question.
Note: Since confirmation dialogs disrupt user task flow, do not provide confirmation dialogs for actions that are easily reversed or insignificant.

For accessibility reasons, we have on PatternFly to add a tooltip just for semantic icons (not decorative icons) that don't have labels (e.g., a trash can icon would have a tooltip reading "Delete"). A tooltip isn't needed for buttons or anything else with labels. So we could say something like,
For semantic icons without labels, add a label inside a tooltip that appears on hover. For more information on accessible icons, see PatternFly's accessibility guide.

timeline.bodyText:
We might also want to add "No." here since that appeared a lot. We should also avoid "e.g." and "i.e." Those sneak into UIs sometimes, but they're not easily understood by all users (especially those who speak a language without Latin roots). So maybe we could just expand this by saying something like,
Only use common and familiar abbreviations, such as "URL." Write out all other abbreviations, especially the following:
- Number: Avoid "No."
- Average: Avoid "avg."
- For example: Avoid "e.g."
- In other words: Avoid "i.e."
For more information on abbreviations and acronyms, see PatternFly's Numerics page in the UX writing style guide.

timeline.bodyText:
This contradicts the PatternFly terminology list since "delete" and "remove" mean different things:
Remove: (v.) Use to describe removing an item from a list, group, view, or other container element without completely deleting it. Also see Add and Delete.
Opposite: Add
Notes: If what you’re removing is not readily apparent from the context, consider adding a noun (like “Remove file”).
We may not want to encourage synonyms since the inconsistency has potential to confuse users (more info in a later comment).

@@ -0,0 +1,91 @@
+[[terminology]]
+= {brandname} Terminology
+
+{brandname} terminology refers to words and phrases specific to {brandname}
+capabilities and features. It is important to use consistent terminology across
+documentation and the code base to avoid unclear or contradictory language.
+
+Add::
+Add an item to an existing list, group, view, or other container element. For example, "add entries to caches".
+
+Cache::
+A data structure for storing key/value pairs in memory.
+
+Cache configuration::
+A resource that instantiates and controls a cache.
+
+Cache template::
+Generally means a resource from which you create cache configurations. +
+{brandname} provides some pre-defined templates (`org.infinispan.*`). +
+Users can define new templates in `infinispan.xml` with the `*-cache-configuration*` tags. +
+In some APIs, you can use the configuration of an existing cache as a template to configure a new cache.
+
+Cache definition::
+Refers to a named cache instance. To avoid ambiguity, do not use in UI or documentation to mean "cache configuration".
+
+Cache Manager::
+Interface for creating and managing caches. Always spell as two words with capital letters when referring to the abstract notion of a Cache Manager. +
+When referring to specific interfaces, use `CacheManager`, `EmbeddedCacheManager`, or `RemoteCacheManager`.
+
+Clear::
+Delete all the elements of a container. For example, "clear entries in a cache".
+
+Create::
+Build something new. For example, "create a cache".
+
+Delete::
+Remove a single element or a group of similar elements from a container. For example, "delete an entry from the cache" or "delete all expired entries from the cache".
+
+Destroy::
+Do not use to mean "delete".
+
+Index::
+Create an index to improve query performance or add an entry to an existing index when it is added to a cache.
+
+Indexes::
+Plural of index. Do not use "indices".
+
+Off-heap::
+Native memory space outside the managed JVM heap. Always hyphenate when used as an adjective.
+
+Purge::
+Can have negative connotations and is not a preferred term. Use only as a synonym for "clear" or "delete" in subsequent descriptions, such as in the body text of a dialog or text that follows a heading. Do not use as a primary verb or in headings.
+
+Query::
+Look up information within the data set. The words "query" and "search" are synonymous but frequently interchanging the two can lead to inconsistency.
++
+Use in verb form: "Query values in the cache." +
+Use in noun form preceded by Ickle: "Perform an Ickle query on the cache."
+
+Reindex::
+Rebuild an index to update or change an existing index. Do not hyphenate (always "reindex" never "re-index").
+
+Remove::
+Use as a synonym for "clear" or "delete" in subsequent descriptions, such as in the body text of a dialog or text that follows a heading. Do not use as a primary verb or in headings.

replies.bodyText:
Thanks Abi. FYI, I added this based on some notes from our doc so we might want to revisit that before we submit any PRs for the console.
"Remove: a synonym for “clear” or “delete” in the body copy/dialog"
There are also some places, particularly in the REST API, where "remove" is used synonymously with "delete". TBH I'm not sure if the distinction between "remove" and "delete" that you're making will apply to Infinispan.
Generally, when we say "remove" something it's deleted, rather than take it out of a container but it still exists. We even use "remove" in the definition for "delete" in this terminology list.
What if we advise using "permanently remove" in places where there is a need to describe "delete"?
